abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fourth Inlands Waterways
            Project for China were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low, the
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: measures to increase efficiency
            and cost effectiveness in the sector are well received by
            the market. Users responded positively to the Project by
            increasing the size of vessels operating in the project
            waterways. Developments similar to the Project can be
            replicated taking advantage of experience gained in inland
            waterway network planning, macro-economic considerations,
            technical design, safety provisions and environmental and
            social safeguards. Overseas training plans designed for
            implementation need to be more realistic and modest with due
            consideration given to government regulations on overseas
            travel. Land acquisition has become more contentious and
            more time has to be given to resolve differences over compensation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of Fourth Inland
            Waterways Project  is to improve access for poor regions of
            southern China by upgrading navigation conditions on the
            region's major east-west river and other waterways
            feeding traffic into the Pearl River Delta region. A
            secondary objective is to harness water flow in two of these
            rivers to generate environmentally clean electricity to help
            meet growing energy demand in the provinces of Guangdong
            Autonomous Region and Guangxi. There are two components,
            each with multi-subcomponents. The first component for
            Guangxi constructs a dam, power station, and shiplock;
            builds access roads; provides bank protection with
            reservoirs and a dam; installs turbines, lock gates, and
            other equipment; supports channel improvement; supports
            institutional strengthening, consultants services, and
            training; and provides finance for resettlement and land
            acquisition, as well as for site management. The second
            component for Guangdong Autonomous Region supports channel
            improvement; replacement of two bridges, construction of a
            dam, power station, shiplock, and access road; the
            installation of turbines, lock gates, and other equipment;
            upgrades navigational aids; the purchase of computer
            hardware for electronic mapping, shiplock management, and a
            management information system; the financing of service
            vessels, services vehicles, a survey, monitoring, and
            ancillary equipment; institutional strengthening, consultant
            services, and training; and land acquisition.
